PERSONALIZED PUBLIC RELATIONS
BY
Marion E. Corwell
Public relations has been defined as "merely human
decency... which flows from a good heart... genuine and
sturdy enough to be reflected in deeds that are admirable
and praiseworthy. "
To most of us, the term, "public relations, M is
thought of as a professional service! a planned campaign
or program to be executed by a paid staff. Since World
War II, the necessity of a well-defined blue print for pub¬
lic relations has been increasingly recognised by manage¬
ment of profit and non-profit organisations alike.
The importance of the major tool of the public rel¬
ations expert -- publicity -- cannot be minimised. A sta¬
tion may be convinced its broadcast offerings are the best
in its market, but if its potential audience is not induced to
listen or watch, the effort for quality programming is lost.
The advice of KNME’s Thomas Petry in the March-April,
I960, NAEB Journal is excellent: "Better the product--
then advertise!"
